Prior knowledge distillation techniques cannot be utilized to produce student models with different vocabularies from the original teacher models due to the requirement of sharing the same vocabulary and output space.
answers: While there has been existing work on reducing NLP model vocabulary sizes BIBREF15, distillation techniques cannot utilize these, since they require the student and teacher models to share the same vocabulary and output space. The article discusses the use of compound probabilistic models, specifically compound probabilistic context-free grammars (CPCFGs), for natural language processing tasks. It argues that these models can capture longer-range dependencies and improve performance compared to traditional probabilistic context-free grammars (PCFGs) and other statistical models. The article also discusses the challenges of training and inference in CPCFGs and proposes solutions using approximate inference and neural network parameterization. The results on several benchmark datasets show that CPCFGs outperform PCFGs and other models on
The backoff strategies involve falling back on a neutral word, a background model, or a generic word recognizer when the foreground model fails to recognize a word.
answers: In pass-through, the recognizer passes on the possibly misspelled word, backoff to neutral word backs off to a word with similar distribution across classes and backoff to background model backs off to a more generic word recognition model trained with larger and less specialized corpus.

Pass-through passes the possibly misspelled word as is, backoff to neutral word backs off to a word with similar distribution across classes and backoff to background model backs off to a more generic word recognition model trained with larger and less specialized corpus.
Backoff to "a" when an UNK-predicted word is encountered, backoff to a more generic word recognition model when the model predicts UNK

The capabilities of the model to capture argumentation depend on the register and topic, the length of the document, and the literary devices used for expressing argumentation.
The datasets were annotated by human raters following specific guidelines.
answers: 1. Each annotator must assign an integer score between 0 and 6 (inclusive) indicating how semantically similar the two words in a given pair are. A score of 6 indicates very high similarity (i.e., perfect synonymy), while zero indicates no similarity., 2. Each annotator must score the entire set of 1,888 pairs in the dataset.,  able to use external sources (e.g. dictionaries, thesauri, WordNet) if required, not able to communicate with each other during the annotation process

pred: The article discusses the challenges of applying argumentation theories to actual data on the web, including the presence of rhetorical devices such as narratives, rhetorical questions, and figurative language, as well as the need to filter out non-argumentative content. The article proposes a computational model for identifying argument components based on Toulmin's model, and evaluates its performance on a corpus of user-generated content. The study finds that the model is effective in identifying argument components, but that its performance varies depending on the type of data and the specific argumentation phenomena present.
